intro: Caryocar krukovii, commonly known as the Brazilian chestnut, is a member of the Sapotaceae family and is native to South America. It is a small to medium-sized tree that can grow up to 15 meters tall, featuring smooth, gray bark and simple, alternate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers followed by oval, woody fruits that contain a single large seed. Its botanical characteristics make it an important species in tropical ecosystems, though it is not widely cultivated for commercial purposes.
